fields.Org Description: The Harvard Humanitarian Initiative (HHI) is a university-wide academic and research center in humanitarian crisis and leadership. Our mission is to create new knowledge and advance evidence-based leadership in disasters and humanitarian crisis. Our work focuses on two main areas: the Humanitarian Academy at Harvard and Research & Translation.

fields.Project Description: Humanitarian Geoanalytics integrates spatial data analysis, mapping, and field-based research to support humanitarian operations. It focuses on conflict dynamics, displacement, and vulnerability assessments using geospatial methods.

The Signal Program explores how emerging technologies—such as remote sensing and data analytics—can support protection in humanitarian emergencies. It develops tools, ethical frameworks, and applied research for crisis contexts.

KoboToolbox is a free and open-source tool designed for mobile data collection in humanitarian crises. It is utilized by UN agencies, NGOs, and governments, offering features such as offline surveys, real-time dashboards, and collaborative field assessments.

HHI Conferences is an academic and applied research center dedicated to advancing humanitarian response through evidence-based practice, data science, and technology. The center serves as a bridge between academia, practitioners, and policy stakeholders.

name: HeiGIT: Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology

fields.Org Full Name: HeiGIT: Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology
fields.Org Description:
HeiGIT (Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology) advances geoinformation technology for societal and environmental benefit. It bridges the gap between fundamental research in geoinformatics and practical applications by developing innovative tools and methods. Its work includes customized geodata for humanitarian missions and intelligent routing for disaster response and climate action.

Using advances in spatial data processing and machine learning, it enriches and analyzes geodata such as OpenStreetMap, providing free tools and insights to researchers, public authorities, and non-profit organizations.

fields.Project Description: The Climate Action Navigator delivers climate action indicators tailored to specific cities. Using a framework of high-resolution spatial indicators, it provides actionable insights through data, maps, and reports co-developed with our partners. The dashboard integrates multiple data sources, including OpenStreetMap (OSM), openrouteservice (ORS), satellite imagery, and scientific research, ensuring comprehensive and reliable insights for decision-makers.

The ohsome dashboard enables users to analyze OSM’s full-history data without programming skills. It generates accurate statistics and plots them directly in the dashboard, allowing for customizable filtering and grouping of tags and types across any region or time period. The ohsome quality API (OQAPI) provides access to OSM data quality information for specific regions and use-cases which might benefit i.e. humanitarian organizations and public administration.

Openrouteservice is an open-source platform leveraging OpenStreetMap data to provide advanced mobility and accessibility analysis. Surrounding the core engine is a vibrant ecosystem of services and tools, enabling seamless integration into diverse projects. We are committed to transparency, making our tools and research freely accessible. Our interactive map client highlights the platform’s capabilities and is available for anyone to explore.

In the face of growing humanitarian challenges, HeiGIT positions geoinformation as a central tool for enhancing crisis response, supporting environmental sustainability, and strengthening community resilience. By leveraging data and digital technologies, it assists humanitarian organizations in identifying vulnerabilities and hazards through risk assessments, integrating local knowledge to ensure context-specific and inclusive solutions. Through its geospatial expertise, HeiGIT pursues faster, smarter, and more effective humanitarian responses.

fields.Org Description: The Barcelona School of Economics (BSE) was founded in 2006 by Andreu Mas-Colell as an institution for scientific cooperation between four academic units: two university departments and two research centers with a long tradition of collaboration and a history of leadership in the field of Economics.

fields.Project Description: Conflict Forecast specializes in conflict forecasting, prevention, and decision support. The forecasting methodology is explicitly designed to detect new, subtle signals of conflict risk in countries not currently at war. Detecting these risks is extremely difficult and requires accepting false positives. These predictions are then integrated into a novel policy evaluation tool to assess the tradeoff between the benefits of preventive action and the costs of acting on false-positive signals.

fields.Org Description: UNICEF’s Data Team is the global go-to for data on children. It leads the collection, validation, analysis, use and communication of the most statistically sound, internationally comparable data on the situation of children and women around the world.

fields.Project Description: Since the mid-1990s, more than 120 countries have conducted one or more Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), generating data on key indicators related to the well-being of children and supporting the development of policies aimed at improving their lives.

fields.Project/Product Name: The State of the World’s Children Report
fields.Project Description: Published annually by UNICEF, The State of the World’s Children report is a flagship global publication that presents comprehensive data and analysis on issues affecting children’s well-being. Each edition focuses on a specific theme—such as nutrition, mental health, or education—and includes rigorous data from household surveys, administrative sources, and UNICEF’s global monitoring systems. The report serves as a key advocacy and programming resource for policymakers and humanitarian actors, offering evidence-based recommendations grounded in global and regional trends.

fields.Project/Product Name: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP)
fields.Project Description: Tracks access to water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) using global indicators and household survey data accessible under open access licenses.

UNICEF is recognized as the world’s leading source of data on children and maintains databases containing hundreds of internationally valid and comparable indicators. With this extensive wealth of information, the UNICEF Data Warehouse is designed to provide easy access to these indicators across a wide range of countries, with some datasets extending back several decades.

name: WFP: United Nations World Food Programme

fields.Org Full Name: WFP: United Nations World Food Programme
fields.Org Description: We work to enhance nutrition in women and children, support smallholder farmers in improving productivity and reducing losses, help countries and communities prepare for and cope with climate-related shocks, and boost human capital through school feeding programmes.

fields.Project Description: This dataset contains dekadal rainfall indicators computed from Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation satellite imagery combined with in situ station data (CHIRPS) version 2. The data is aggregated by subnational administrative units for the asset Rainfall Indicators.

HungerMapLIVE is the World Food Programme (WFP)’s global hunger monitoring system. It combines key metrics from various data sources—such as food security information, weather, population size, conflict, hazards, nutrition information, and macro-economic data—to help assess, monitor, and predict the magnitude and severity of hunger in near real-time. The resulting analysis is displayed on an interactive map that enables WFP staff, key decision makers, and the broader humanitarian community to make more informed and timely decisions relating to food security.

fields.Project/Product Name: Platform for Real-Time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM)
fields.Project Description: PRISM is a climate risk monitoring system that integrates geospatial data on hazards such as droughts, floods, tropical storms, and earthquakes, along with socioeconomic vulnerability information. It provides decision-makers with interactive maps and charts to support disaster risk reduction and social assistance programs for the asset Platform for Real-Time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM).

This dataset contains information on countries, commodities, and markets, sourced from the World Food Programme Price Database. Due to the large volume of data, the actual food prices are provided in country-level datasets. The World Food Programme Price Database includes data on foods such as maize, rice, beans, fish, and sugar, covering 98 countries and approximately 3,000 markets. The database is updated weekly, though much of the data is reported on a monthly basis. Historical data is available as far back as 1992 for a few countries, while many others began reporting from 2003 or later.

The WFP Innovation Forum is a global platform that showcases groundbreaking solutions to address food insecurity and humanitarian challenges. Bringing together innovators, humanitarian actors, private sector leaders, and policymakers, the forum highlights cutting-edge technologies, from AI-powered disaster response to sustainable agriculture, that are transforming the way hunger and crises are tackled around the world.

The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture comprehensive multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. Implemented by IMPACT Initiatives through its REACH Initiative, the MSNA collects statistically representative, household-level data on sectors such as food security, health, shelter, WASH, education, and protection. While the initiative is closely coordinated with OCHA and humanitarian clusters in country-led responses, the technical design, survey implementation, and analysis are primarily led by REACH/IMPACT, with operational support from agencies like IOM , WFP or IMMAP.

fields.Org Description: The Netherlands Red Cross‘ data and digital unit 510 aims to help every National Red Cross and Red Crescent Society in need anywhere. It is named after the total surface area of the earth (510 million square kilometres). 510 started in 2016 with a core team of 3 and never stopped growing. Currently, 510 has more than 100 team members, of whom 70+ are professional volunteers and academic students.

fields.Project Description: A new generation risk data initiative is shining a light on where climate, conflict, and displacement risks collide across sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa, and the Middle East (MENA). By integrating these drivers into one analytical stream, it delivers actionable insights tailored to conflict-affected and climate-vulnerable populations, filling critical gaps and enabling anticipatory action. Led by the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre, together with the Netherlands Red Cross’ 510 Initiative and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), the risk data supports more informed and anticipatory decision-making across the humanitarian system.

Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

The 510 Data Team supports innovation by implementing data science projects focused on disaster preparedness, local early warning systems, and the development of big data tools throughout the Red Cross network.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs (MEAE)
Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands (BZ / MFA)
Ministry of Education, Culture, and Science (OCW)

name: OHCHR: United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights

fields.Org Full Name: OHCHR: United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
fields.Org Description: The High Commissioner for Human Rights is the principal human rights official of the United Nations. The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights is accountable to the Secretary-General and is responsible for all the activities of OHCHR, as well as for its administration.

fields.Project Description: The Rapid Assessment Data project accelerates the reporting of conflict-related violence in fragile settings by automating data gathering from open and established sources and integrating Machine Learning (ML) driven analysis. The project’s impacts include enhanced risk assessment, more targeted interventions, and the empowerment of at-risk populations to advocate for protective measures.

name: CRED: Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters

fields.Org Full Name: CRED: Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters
fields.Org Description: The Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters (CRED  has been active for over 50 years and is recognized as a reference institution in the field of disasters and emergency situations: CRED promotes research, training, and technical expertise in humanitarian emergencies, particularly in public health and epidemiology. Its main research topic is natural disasters. By providing a wealth of data related to health, the centre aims to improve disasters preparedness and response. CRED is managing the EM-DAT database, quantifying the occurrence, human and economic impacts associated with natural and technological disasters.

fields.Project Description: EM-DAT compiles free, searchable global records of natural and technological disasters dating back to 1900. It provides standardized event-level data that is extensively used in disaster risk research, policy analysis, and early warning modeling.

fields.Org Description: UNFPA, the United Nations Population Fund, works globally to ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health, prevent and respond to gender-based violence, collect and use population data, and promote gender equality and the empowerment of women and youth across the humanitarian/development continuum.

fields.Project Description: UNFPA, the United Nations Population Fund, works globally to ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health, prevent and respond to gender-based violence, collect and use population data, and promote gender equality and the empowerment of women and youth across the humanitarian and development continuum.

The Population Data Portal serves as UNFPA’s comprehensive data source and tracker for population and development statistics. It brings together the latest data on topics such as sexual and reproductive health and rights, family planning, maternal health, and gender-based violence, collected from a variety of sources. The portal provides users with reliable, up-to-date information to support research, policy-making, and program development in the field of population and development.

fields.Project/Product Name: GRID3: Geo-Referenced Infrastructure and Demographic Data for Development
fields.Project Description: GRID3 provides high-resolution geospatial data, including population estimates, infrastructure mapping, and administrative boundaries, to support governments and organizations in planning, monitoring, and delivering services effectively.

The World Population Dashboard presents comprehensive global population data, including statistics on fertility rates, gender parity in school enrolment, and information related to sexual and reproductive health, among other key indicators. These data collectively provide insight into the health and rights of populations worldwide, with a particular focus on women and young people. The figures are sourced from UNFPA and other United Nations agencies, and are updated on an annual basis.

fields.Org Description: The Feminist Humanitarian Network (FHN) is a global collective of feminist leaders working together to transform the humanitarian system into one that is guided by feminist principles.

fields.Project/Product Name: Kente Threads: Weaving leadership from displacement data
fields.Project Description: Kente Threads is a feminist initiative that reimagines humanitarian action by centering refugee women’s resilience and lived experiences.

fields.Org Description: UN Women is the United Nations entity dedicated to gender equality and the empowerment of women. A global champion for women and girls, UN Women was established to accelerate progress on meeting their needs worldwide.

fields.Project/Product Name: Transformative Outcomes: Leveraging Crisis Data in conflict
fields.Project Description: The Transformative Outcomes project deploys an interactive web platform and standardized analysis toolkit to deliver high-quality crisis data for vulnerable populations in conflict-affected settings. This promotes evidence-based planning, targeted interventions, and capacity building among local actors, humanitarian agencies, and policymakers. CRAF’d funding supports data collection in six pilot countries, platform development, and training, catalyzing scalable, accessible data as a global public good.

A first-of-its-kind global dataset on women’s roles
in non-state armed groups is set to enhance peacebuilding across 500 women’s wings of non-state
armed groups. Led by the University of Denver in
collaboration with research partners, the project will
inform programming in conflict-affected settings.

UN Women’s strategy for change, Women Count, seeks to bring about a radical shift in how gender statistics are used, created, and promoted. The initiative aims to transform the landscape of gender data by improving the production, accessibility, and utilization of gender statistics. Women Count works to ensure that reliable and comprehensive gender data informs policies, programs, and decision-making processes, ultimately advancing gender equality and empowering women and girls globally.

fields.Org Description: The US Geological Survey maintains extensive data services and conducts numerous data-related projects across various fields, including mapping mineral resources, analyzing global supply chains, and conducting environmental monitoring and research. Projects often involve collaborations with other governmental agencies, universities, and private companies. For example, USGS offers technical assistance internationally, with expertise in areas like seismic monitoring and water resource assessment. Their Community for Data Integration (CDI) supports data-driven research by funding projects that enhance data analysis tools, such as the Terrestrial Remote Sensing Data Ingestion with PyHAT, which facilitates the use of multiple terrestrial datasets for machine learning analysis.

fields.Project Description: USGS systems offer real-time search and visualization of earthquake data, global hazards, and geophysical datasets. These systems support crisis response and scientific analysis through open APIs. The Earthquakes Maps asset provides users with interactive tools to explore recent seismic activity, access detailed event information, and analyze geophysical trends, facilitating informed decision-making and research.

name: UNODA: United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs

fields.Org Full Name: UNODA: United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs
fields.Org Description: UNODA provides substantive and organizational support for norm-setting in the area of disarmament through the work of the General Assembly and its First Committee, the Disarmament Commission, the Conference on Disarmament and other bodies. It fosters disarmament measures through dialogue, transparency and confidence-building on military matters, and encourages regional disarmament efforts; these include the United Nations Register of Conventional Arms and regional forums.

fields.Project Description: The UN General Assembly established the UN Register of Conventional Arms (UNROCA) in 1991 through resolution 46/36 L to promote transparency in armaments. Through the UNROCA instrument, Member States are requested, on an annual basis, to report their international transfers of seven categories of major conventional arms, as well as small arms and light weapons. They may also provide additional background information, such as data on military holdings and procurement through national production. To date, 175 Member States have reported to the UNROCA instrument at least once. In light of relatively consistent reporting by the world’s largest arms exporters, it is estimated that the Register captures around 90 percent of the volume of the global arms trade.

fields.Project/Product Name: United Nations Report on Military Expenditures (UNMilEx)
fields.Project Description: UNODA publishes annual data on military spending from Member States, informing arms control and global transparency through structured datasets.

fields.Org Description: Global Pulse is an initiative of the United Nations focused on harnessing big data, artificial intelligence, and emerging technologies to support sustainable development and humanitarian action. The organization collaborates with UN agencies, governments, and partners worldwide to analyze real-time data and generate insights that inform decision-making. By leveraging advanced analytics, Global Pulse aims to improve crisis response, monitor global trends, and promote data-driven policies.

fields.Project Description: Data Insights for Social & Humanitarian Action, also known as DISHA, is a multi-partner initiative led by UN Global Pulse, the Secretary-General’s Innovation Lab. The initiative aims to accelerate ethical and responsible access to data and artificial intelligence (AI) solutions in order to unlock social impact at scale.

fields.Org Description: The University of Edinburgh is a public research university based in Edinburgh, Scotland. Founded by the town council under the authority of a royal charter from King James VI in 1582 and officially opened in 1583, it is one of Scotland's four ancient universities and the sixth-oldest university in continuous operation in the English-speaking world.

fields.Project Description: PeaceRep distributes the PA-X Tracker, an innovative digital tool designed to provide data-driven insights that support peace and transition processes. The suite of PeaceTech tools within the PA-X Tracker enables users to track and monitor the progress and implementation of peace and transition initiatives. The Tracker offers a comprehensive understanding of how peace processes are unfolding, identifies the stakeholders involved, and assesses the impact of these processes across a range of institutional, political, economic, humanitarian, and security indicators.

fields.Org Description: Humanitarian Outcomes is an independent research organisation providing evidence and policy advice to inform better humanitarian action.

fields.Project Description: GDHO is a global compendium of organisations that provide aid in humanitarian crises. The database includes basic organisational and operational information on these humanitarian providers, which include international non-governmental organisations (grouped by federation), national NGOs that deliver aid within their own borders, UN humanitarian agencies, and the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement.

CORE is the latest data-driven initiative by Humanitarian Outcomes to provide quantifiable measures on the size of the humanitarian sector as well as its capacity and reach in crisis-affected countries.

The Aid Worker Security Database (AWSD) records major incidents of violence against aid workers, with incident reports spanning from 1997 to the present. Initiated in 2005, the AWSD remains the sole comprehensive global source of these data, providing the evidence base for analysis of the changing security environment for civilian aid operations.

fields.Org Description: The University of Stirling builds its academic identity around research-informed social science, environmental studies, and behavioral science, integrating interdisciplinary approaches with a campus designed to support empirical fieldwork, sports science development, and public policy analysis.

fields.Project Description: PeaceRep distributes the PA-X Tracker, an innovative digital tool designed to provide data-driven insights that support peace and transition processes. The suite of PeaceTech tools within the PA-X Tracker enables users to track and monitor the progress and implementation of peace and transition initiatives. The Tracker offers a comprehensive understanding of how peace processes are unfolding, identifies the stakeholders involved, and assesses the impact of these processes across a range of institutional, political, economic, humanitarian, and security indicators.

fields.Org Description: UNDP works in about 170 countries and territories, helping to eradicate poverty, reduce inequalities and exclusion, and build resilience so countries can sustain progress. As the UN’s development agency, UNDP plays a critical role in helping countries achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.

fields.Project Description: The Risk Anticipation Data Hub, a project of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), is a transformative open-access data platform. This comprehensive data warehouse contains over 15,000 indicators, integrating processed and cleaned public datasets that cover a wide range of risk factors. Utilizing advanced technology, including a generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) interface and real-time analytics, the Data Hub provides ecosystem partners with essential data and insights. These resources support improved crisis anticipation, prevention, and response, enabling more informed decision-making and effective action.

INFORM Warning is a state-of-the-art, innovative global risk monitoring tool designed to anticipate complex risks up to a year in advance, directly linked to crisis funding instruments. It transcends traditional methods by presenting multi-hazard information from diverse sources. Its unique analysis offers insights into risk trends, forecasts, scenarios, and potential events leading to crisis impact.

The Data Futures Exchange is an open-source platform designed to serve as a central hub for data innovation, with a particular emphasis on development impact. The platform is aligned with the thematic priorities of the United Nations Development Programme and utilizes a systemic approach combined with advanced analytics to identify actions that accelerate sustainable development on a global scale.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)

fields.Org Description: The Centre for Humanitarian Data is focused on increasing the use and impact of data in the humanitarian sector. It is managed by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). As part of OCHA’s Information Management Branch, the Centre’s role is to enable the organization to deliver on its ambition to be more data-driven and analytical, and to ensure a responsible approach to technology and data management.

fields.Project Description: HXL is a simple standard designed for messy data. It uses HXL hashtags to accelerate data processing and enable interoperability across various data sources.

The Humanitarian Data Forum provides an opportunity for members of the data community to reconnect and collaborate. The inaugural Forum, held in The Hague, brought together over 160 participants from 42 countries to help shape the future of humanitarian data. Attendees represented a diverse range of organizations, including UN agencies, local and global NGOs, governments, the private sector, and academia.

Managed by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) is a centralized platform for sharing humanitarian data. It offers access to over 20,000 datasets from more than 300 organizations, covering themes such as population, conflict, health, and displacement. HDX includes the Data Grid and the COVID-19 Data Explorer, and it plays a crucial role in promoting data transparency, interoperability, and informed decision-making in humanitarian settings.

The initial scope of HDX HAPI was aligned with that of the HDX Data Grids, focusing on providing the foundational data required to understand humanitarian contexts. Over time, the scope of HDX HAPI has expanded beyond the original Data Grids to encompass a broader range of data. A live dashboard is available to monitor data availability by country.

HDX Signals is a product and service provided by the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) that monitors key datasets and generates automated notifications via email when significant, negative changes are detected. The system is designed to support timely decision-making by alerting users to important shifts in humanitarian data.

name: FSNWG: Food Security and Nutrition Working Group

fields.Org Full Name: FSNWG: Food Security and Nutrition Working Group
fields.Org Description: The Food Security and Nutrition Working Group (FSNWG) is a regional platform, currently co-chaired by ICPAC and FAO. It’s goal is two-fold: to provide an up-to-date food security and nutrition situation analysis (early warning) and to offer a forum to build consensus on critical issues facing policy and interventions. The FNSWG has served regional governments, donors, and non-governmental agencies since the early 2000’s. Current membership includes approximately 80 organisations (IGAD, UN agencies, NGOs, donors, and research institutions) who contribute to the operation of the working group, and its nutrition, markets, food security information, livestock and pastoralist sub-groups.

fields.Project Description: FNWG Alerts and Early Warning provides timely notifications and early warnings regarding potential risks and emerging threats relevant to the asset. The service delivers clear, concise, and actionable information to support informed decision-making and proactive risk management. All alerts are presented in a neutral and descriptive manner, ensuring that stakeholders receive accurate and objective updates.

The Global Seismic Risk Map  poster comprises three global maps, and a ranking of the top 15 countries according to five risk metrics. The main map presents the geographic distribution of average annual loss (AAL) of the built-up area due to ground shaking in the residential, commercial and industrial building stock. It does not consider the effects of tsunamis, liquefaction, landslides, and fires following earthquakes.

The Food Security and Nutrition Working Group (FSNWG) is a regional platform, currently co-chaired by ICPAC and FAO. It’s goal is two-fold: to provide an up-to-date food security and nutrition situation analysis (early warning) and to offer a forum to build consensus on critical issues facing policy and interventions. The FNSWG has served regional governments, donors, and non-governmental agencies since the early 2000’s. Current membership includes approximately 80 organisations (IGAD, UN agencies, NGOs, donors, and research institutions) who contribute to the operation of the working group, and its nutrition, markets, food security information, livestock and pastoralist sub-groups.

name: UNOSAT: The United Nations Satellite Centre

fields.Org Full Name: UNOSAT: The United Nations Satellite Centre
fields.Org Description: The United Nations Satellite Centre (UNOSAT), part of UNITAR, delivers satellite analysis, training, and capacity development to UN entities and Member States. We leverage geospatial technologies to support humanitarian response, sustainable development, and resilience building worldwide.

fields.Project Description: UNOSAT provides geospatial analysis and satellite imagery to support disaster response, humanitarian aid, and sustainable development. It offers on-demand and open-access mapping services through interactive portals, data hubs, and geospatial APIs.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS)
fields.Project Description: The Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) is a cooperation framework between the United Nations, the European Commission, and disaster managers worldwide. Its purpose is to improve alerts, facilitate information exchange, and enhance coordination during the initial phase following major sudden-onset disasters.

fields.Org Description: Pacific Disaster Center (PDC) is a leading scientific innovator of global risk reduction science and technology. As a University of Hawai’i applied science and research center, our work intersects with a variety of government, community, academic, and scientific organizations at home and around the world to build resilience to natural and man-made hazards, assess risk, and enhance the capacity to quickly and accurately anticipate and prepare for new and emerging threats.

fields.Project Description: PDC’s National Disaster Preparedness Baseline Assessment is more than an assessment. It is a long-term program designed to help countries evaluate risk and disaster management capacity and apply these insights to early warning, disaster preparedness, policy and planning, sustainable development, and resilience-building initiatives. The national baseline assessment is the only U.S. program recognized by the United Nations to assist countries in operationalizing the goals of the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction. It provides an evidence-based foundation for actions to be taken and investments to be made in achieving long-term resilience and strengthening national disaster preparedness.

DisasterAWARE is a global platform that provides real-time hazard alerts, dashboards, and geospatial tools to support disaster preparedness and early warning. The platform integrates predictive models and hazard tracking using data from global datasets, enabling comprehensive monitoring and response to potential disasters.

PDC’s advanced natural language processing and generative AI are being leveraged to greatly reduce the manual labor and time involved with finding, analyzing, and curating global hazard content. This enables PDC to provide more comprehensive coverage of hazard events worldwide through its DisasterAWARE Pro risk intelligence and early warning platform. These repetitive and time-consuming tasks are now performed by AI Hazard Finder with greater speed and accuracy than previously possible.

PDC’s Multi-hazard Risk Score combines multi-hazard exposure, vulnerability (susceptibility to impact), and coping capacity (the relative ability to absorb negative disaster impacts). This score provides a comprehensive measure of how each country may be affected by hazards and disasters as a whole over time.

Learn the basics and progress to becoming an advanced user in DisasterAWARE software. On-site, instructor-led classroom training is available at either the client’s location or the provider’s facilities. Support is offered to help achieve nearly any training objective.

fields.Org Description: Uppsala University is the oldest Nordic university, founded in 1477. Today we are a comprehensive research university with a clear mission: to pursue top-quality research and education and to interact constructively with society, thus contributing to a better world.

fields.Project Description: The Violence & Impacts Early-Warning System (VIEWS) is an academic research consortium and conflict prediction system jointly led by Uppsala University and the Peace Research Institute Oslo. The VIEWS consortium brings together a suite of interrelated projects dedicated to exploring state-of-the-art approaches for studying and predicting the risk of violent conflicts and their impacts on society and human development.
UCDP offers conflict datasets, battle event data, and fatalities statistics to support academic and policy research on global violence trends.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry of Education and Research / Swedish Research Council (VR)

name: SIPRI: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute

fields.Org Full Name: SIPRI: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute
fields.Org Description: SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources, to policymakers, researchers, media and the interested public. Based in Stockholm, SIPRI is regularly ranked among the most respected think tanks worldwide.

fields.Project Description: An open library of global arms production data, featuring company listings, production volumes, and export trends for use in disarmament analysis and policy design.
Offers historical data on military spending by country, allowing trend analysis and budget comparisons for global peace research.
This database tracks country participation in UN and regional peace operations, including details on troop numbers, funding, and deployment dates.

fields.Project/Product Name: Stockholm Forum on Peace and Development
fields.Project Description: Held annually, the Stockholm Forum on Peace and Development is a dialogue-driven event that offers a neutral platform for interdisciplinary exchange among members of international communities working in development, humanitarian, peacebuilding, and security sectors. The event is recognized for its discussion-led roundtable sessions, which are developed in collaboration with partner organizations and encourage active participation from stakeholders at all levels.
Provides publicly available datasets on the legal transfers of major conventional weapons between countries. The database is widely used in security and disarmament monitoring.

fields.Project/Product Name: SIPRI Mapping ATT-Relevant Cooperation and Assistance Activities Database
fields.Project Description: Tracks international arms transfer assistance and cooperation initiatives. It supports transparency and reporting under the Arms Trade Treaty through searchable data.

The SIPRI National Budget Archive provides government spending data from multiple countries, facilitating transparent comparisons of military and civilian budget priorities. This resource supports analysis related to disarmament and peacebuilding by offering comprehensive and accessible budget information.

name: UNMAS: United Nations Mine Action Service

fields.Org Full Name: UNMAS: United Nations Mine Action Service
fields.Org Description: UNMAS (United Nations Mine Action Service) utilizes data to inform and manage mine action programs globally, coordinating with other UN entities and partners. They maintain an Interactive Dashboard of the UN Mine Action Strategy, which presents data on program outcomes, outputs, targeted populations, and funding. UNMAS also collaborates on data-related projects, including a machine learning initiative to detect development indicators in cleared areas of Afghanistan using satellite imagery, which informs their efforts to eliminate the threat of mines and explosives.

Flowminder also co-founded, in partnership with UNFPA, WorldPop at the University of Southampton, and CIESIN at Columbia University the GRID3 programme. GRID3 was an international partnership programme funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the United Kingdom’s Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office to map a path to sustainable development for everyone with geospatial data solutions.

fields.Project Description: Flowminder strengthens the capacity of governments, UN agencies, mobile operators, private companies, and NGOs to maximize the benefits of new analytic techniques and data sources. Through expertise in geospatial and mobile operator data analytics, Flowminder collaborates with in-country partners to enhance data use among decision makers and to develop sustainable, long-lasting solutions.

To provide decision makers with precise and accurate estimates of population changes and movements, and thereby support interventions in sectors such as health and disaster management, state-of-the-art methods have been developed for estimating population distribution and human mobility using mobile phone usage data, specifically Call Detail Records (CDRs), as well as survey, census, and geospatial data. CDRs are datasets automatically generated by mobile operators for billing purposes, regardless of phone type, and represent an attractive data source for estimating internal migration and displacement, particularly in low- and middle-income countries where data on human mobility are often scarce. These methods enable a more comprehensive understanding of population dynamics, supporting evidence-based decision making in critical sectors.

To maximise the use of public and private sites and services, such as schools, health facilities, vaccination sites, or mobile money agents, these facilities need to be located where they can reach the largest possible share of the population. Today, detailed data on population distributions, roads and river networks, population mobility patterns, and a range of other geospatial data are available, enabling decision makers to better identify service allocation issues. Using these data, Flowminder has developed a new methodology to support decision makers in identifying optimal locations for their services and to facilitate data-driven decision making.

FlowKit is an open-source suite for the secure processing of de-identified mobile network data, designed to bridge the gap between mobile operators and humanitarian or development actors. By providing operator-controlled, audited access to mobility metrics via a dedicated API, FlowKit reduces technical barriers, safeguards privacy, and enables the scalable use of mobile data for crisis response, planning, and public-good analytics.

fields.Project/Product Name: GRID3: Geo-Referenced Infrastructure and Demographic Data for Development
fields.Project Description: GRID3 provides high-resolution geospatial data, including population estimates, infrastructure mapping, and administrative boundaries, to support governments and organizations in planning, monitoring, and delivering services effectively.

name: OCHA: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

fields.Org Full Name: OCHA: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
fields.Org Description: Support humanitarian organizations to respond effectively to the needs of people caught in crises, to understand and analyse their needs, and to mobilize international assistance. We provide tools and services to help humanitarian organizations ensure that no one affected by a crisis is left behind.
fields.Org IATI Name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

fields.Project Description: Common Operational Datasets (CODs) are authoritative reference datasets utilized by humanitarian organizations to support response efforts and inform decision-making. They offer a consistent and standardized data framework that enables all actors involved in a crisis to coordinate effectively.

OCHA’s Common Operational Data Administrative Boundaries (COD‑AB) is a curated, harmonized global dataset aligned with OCHA’s COD standard. It is designed to support mapping, analysis, and coordination in humanitarian operations.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Humanitarian Operational Presence Who, What, Where (3W) Portal
fields.Project Description: The 3W data is sourced from OCHA country and regional offices around the world and compiled by the Field Information Services (FIS) Section of OCHA. The data are as provided, and organization names and acronyms are not standardized. The frequency of 3W data collection varies across offices, and the compiled database includes what is available up to the date of publishing. This information supports the asset Global Humanitarian Operational Presence Who, What, Where (3W) Portal.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS)
fields.Project Description: The Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) is a cooperation framework between the United Nations, the European Commission, and disaster managers worldwide. Its purpose is to improve alerts, facilitate information exchange, and enhance coordination during the initial phase following major sudden-onset disasters.

OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS) collects, standardizes, and publishes real-time humanitarian funding data globally. It provides dashboards and downloadable datasets that track donor and recipient transactions during emergencies, ensuring transparency across funding flows.

The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture comprehensive multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. Implemented by IMPACT Initiatives through its REACH Initiative, the MSNA collects statistically representative, household-level data on sectors such as food security, health, shelter, WASH, education, and protection. While the initiative is closely coordinated with OCHA and humanitarian clusters in country-led responses, the technical design, survey implementation, and analysis are primarily led by REACH/IMPACT, with operational support from agencies like IOM , WFP or IMMAP.

fields.Org Description: The Peace Research Institute Oslo (PRIO) conducts research on the conditions for peaceful relations between states, groups and people.

fields.Project Description: The Violence & Impacts Early-Warning System (VIEWS) is an academic research consortium and conflict prediction system jointly led by Uppsala University and the Peace Research Institute Oslo. The VIEWS consortium brings together a suite of interrelated projects dedicated to exploring state-of-the-art approaches for studying and predicting the risk of violent conflicts and their impacts on society and human development.

Since the end of World War II, the practice of peace mediation was restricted to diplomatic circles and international organizations, such as the United Nations. In recent decades, however, the field has witnessed the emergence of a new group of non-governmental actors known as Peace Facilitation Organizations (PFOs). PFOs are defined as independent organizations whose work consists of facilitating, advising, supporting, or implementing peace mediation or dialogue initiatives. The PFOs mapping dataset documents the PFOs that currently operate worldwide and provides information on their background, structure, approach, modus operandi, funding model, and other characteristics. The mapping aims to shed light on this field and identify these organizations, primarily from Western countries, that have professionalized peace mediation and contributed a certain degree of dexterity and standardization to peace processes.
UCDP offers conflict datasets, battle event data, and fatalities statistics to support academic and policy research on global violence trends.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry of Education and Research / Swedish Research Council (VR)

fields.Project/Product Name: EMPOW: Women’s Empowerment in Peace Processes
fields.Project Description: EMPOW will address the data gap on Women, Peace and Security (WPS) by creating interoperable datasets: EMPOW Agency and EMPOW Reform. The objective is to generate and harmonize data on women's empowerment across all peace process phases—from pre-negotiations to post-war peacebuilding—and ensure compatibility with leading crisis data, such as the Uppsala Conflict Data Program.

fields.Project/Product Name: NYU + VIEWS: Data for Peace Conference
fields.Project Description: The Data for Peace Conference gathers national and international stakeholders for a multi-day hybrid programme focused on leveraging data, analytics, and emerging technologies for peacebuilding and prevention. Through panels, workshops, pitches, and networking sessions, the event strengthens collaboration across the humanitarian–development–peace and climate sectors and promotes practical capacity building for the global data-for-peace community.

name: FEWS NET: Famine Early Warning Systems Network

fields.Org Full Name: FEWS NET: Famine Early Warning Systems Network
fields.Org Description: The Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET) is a leading provider of early warning and analysis on acute food insecurity around the world.

Since 2013, Data-Pop Alliance has worked to apply cutting edge data science to solve the world’s most pressing problems. As the 2030 deadline for the UN sustainable development goals approaches, we believe novel approaches are needed to enhance the efficacy of the global development sector and reach those most in need.

fields.Project Description: The Data, Technology & Innovation (DTI) Initiative applies data science, AI, and scalable platform development to create ethical, sustainable digital tools for social impact. Combining dashboards, AI platforms, and applied ML research, it transforms complex datasets into actionable insights that strengthen decision-making for organizations and communities globally.

Data-Pop Alliance Capacity & Training Services build data literacy at scale by integrating technical, policy, and ethical perspectives into a global learning ecosystem. Through workshops, technical courses, and the Open Learning Hub, the initiative enables professionals to navigate opportunities and challenges, apply data science methods to non-traditional data sources, and advance equitable, evidence-driven decision-making across development and humanitarian contexts.

fields.Org Description: INSO provides a coherent, sector-wide response to this need, delivering action-oriented solutions that go beyond saving individual lives to enable humanitarian operations in acutely challenging environments.

fields.Project Description: The Conflict Data Dashboard displays all recorded security incidents, meaning it shows all ‘Security incidents’ as defined above that have been recorded by INSO, not only those that affected NGOs.
The Conflict Data Dashboard presents all recorded security incidents by date, location, type, perpetrator, and the impact on civilians.

fields.Org Description: GEM is a non-profit, scientific, public-private partnership that fosters global collaboration, developing transparent earthquake risk assessment resources for worldwide risk management.

fields.Project Description: The Global Exposure Database (GED) is a spatial dataset developed by GEM that quantifies the exposure of buildings and infrastructure to natural hazards across countries. It encompasses structural typologies, occupancy data, and geographic distributions, allowing users to estimate potential losses from earthquakes and other disasters. GED is openly available and is widely utilized alongside hazard models to inform national disaster risk management strategies and to support resilience in urban development planning.

Territory Seismic Risk Profiles offer consolidated snapshots of seismic hazard and risk through social indicators, exposure and loss metrics, building class information, historical earthquake impacts, and mapped distributions of hazard and vulnerability. Based on 100,000-year simulated event models, they support risk management across residential, commercial, and industrial sectors.

Developed by the Global Earthquake Model (GEM) Foundation, the OpenQuake Platform is an open-source tool for seismic hazard and risk assessment. It provides researchers, engineers, and governments with models, tools, and databases to simulate earthquake impacts, assess vulnerability, and inform urban planning and disaster preparedness strategies. OpenQuake integrates data on seismicity, exposure, and building fragility, and is widely used in both academic research and national risk management initiatives.

The Global Vulnerability Model consists of a set of functions that estimate the consequences of earthquakes of a given intensity to different building typologies. The database is separated by region-country/territory and considers functions for over 3500 building typologies identified in the Global Exposure Model developed, curated and maintained by the GEM Foundation. The fragility functions are derived analytically, using non-linear time-history analyses on equivalent single-degree-of-freedom oscillators and a large set of ground motion records representing several tectonic environments.

The Global Seismic Risk Map  poster comprises three global maps, and a ranking of the top 15 countries according to five risk metrics. The main map presents the geographic distribution of average annual loss (AAL) of the built-up area due to ground shaking in the residential, commercial and industrial building stock. It does not consider the effects of tsunamis, liquefaction, landslides, and fires following earthquakes.

The Global Seismic Hazard Map (GSHM), developed under the auspices of the Global Earthquake Model (GEM), provides probabilistic assessments of earthquake hazards worldwide. It combines global seismicity data, geological models, and ground motion prediction equations to estimate the likelihood of earthquake-induced ground shaking. The GSHM supports disaster risk reduction, urban planning, and insurance risk modeling by offering a harmonized and peer-reviewed reference for national and regional seismic hazard assessments.

fields.Org Description: Fields Data focusses on having data ready before the occurrence of a disaster, thereby saving lives through preparedness and efficient response.

fields.Project Description: In the daily whirlwind, the data avalanche generated is often underestimated. However, there is a significant opportunity in standardizing and organizing this information. Doing so unlocks valuable lessons from the past, enhances efficiency, and supports informed, strategic decision-making.

At the heart of every humanitarian mission lies the critical 3Ws: identifying who is doing what and where. This approach ensures effective coordination, resource allocation, and response by providing a clear overview of the actors involved, their activities, and their locations. The 3W & Connections asset supports humanitarian efforts by mapping these essential elements, enabling organizations to collaborate efficiently and address needs on the ground.

The ROOTS Portal provides a comprehensive dataset on local organizations, featuring a 3W map (Who does What, Where) that outlines the operational presence of both national and international organizations. This platform enables users to access detailed information about the activities and locations of various organizations, supporting coordination and informed decision-making.

Embracing a grassroots ethos, the team forges vital connections on the frontline. Before initiating data collection, they thoroughly explore the digital landscape to identify existing efforts and avoid redundancy. These online insights are then integrated with raw field data, gathered through collaboration with trusted local partners.

fields.Org Description: MapSwipe is a humanitarian crowdsourcing app where volunteers swipe through satellite images to help map vulnerable areas that aid organizations rely on.

fields.Project Description: Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

MapSwipe coordinates volunteer mapping of satellite imagery to create open building and infrastructure datasets in underserved areas. It supports crisis mapping, response planning, and humanitarian targeting.

name: Josef Korbel School, University of Denver

fields.Org Full Name: Josef Korbel School, University of Denver
fields.Org Description: The Josef Korbel School of Global and Public Affairs at the University of Denver is a professional school of international affairs offering undergraduate, graduate, and doctoral degrees. It is named in honor of the founding dean, Josef Korbel, father of former U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright

fields.Project Description:
A first-of-its-kind global dataset on women’s roles
in non-state armed groups is set to enhance peacebuilding across 500 women’s wings of non-state
armed groups. Led by the University of Denver in
collaboration with research partners, the project will
inform programming in conflict-affected settings.

fields.Org Description: Founded in 1956, the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) is Denmark’s largest international NGO, with a specific expertise in forced displacement. DRC is present in close to 40 countries. DRC advocates for the rights of and solutions for displacement-affected communities, and provides assistance during all stages of displacement: In acute crisis, in exile, when settling and integrating in a new place, or upon return. DRC supports displaced persons in becoming self-reliant and included into hosting societies. DRC works with civil society and responsible authorities to promote protection of rights and inclusion.

fields.Project Description: The forecast platform provides predictive models of displacement risk based on conflict, climate, and governance indicators. It offers downloadable datasets and visual forecasts to support anticipatory humanitarian programming.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO)

fields.Org Description: REACH is a leading humanitarian initiative providing granular data, timely information and in-depth analysis from contexts of crisis, disaster and displacement. The work of REACH directly feeds into aid response and decision-making by providing accessible and precise information on the humanitarian situation of crisis-affected populations.

fields.Project Description: The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture comprehensive multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. Implemented by IMPACT Initiatives through its REACH Initiative, the MSNA collects statistically representative, household-level data on sectors such as food security, health, shelter, WASH, education, and protection. While the initiative is closely coordinated with OCHA and humanitarian clusters in country-led responses, the technical design, survey implementation, and analysis are primarily led by REACH/IMPACT, with operational support from agencies like IOM , WFP or IMMAP.

name: UNDPPA: United Nations Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs

fields.Org Full Name: UNDPPA: United Nations Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs
fields.Org Description: The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs (DPPA) plays a central role in United Nations efforts to prevent and resolve conflict around the world. DPPA supports the Secretary-General’s peace initiatives, oversees mediation, political transition and peacebuilding processes, and assists UN Member States as they carry out elections.

fields.Project Description: Developed by the DPPA’s Innovation Cell in collaboration with academic partners, Geoguard is the first-ever geospatial dashboard designed for decision-makers seeking insight on environmental and conflict risks across the Middle East, Central, and West Africa. Utilizing cutting-edge technology, Geoguard aggregates millions of data points on environmental conditions and geo-coded conflict events into an intuitive dashboard, drawing from diverse data sources as well as locally collected or crowd-sourced information. The platform provides immediate insight into environmental risk factors throughout specified regions and offers snapshots in time that are linked to trends in conflict and social unrest.

fields.Org Description: The U.S. Department of State is a federal government agency responsible for leading the nation’s foreign policy and international relations. It represents the United States to other countries, negotiates treaties and agreements, and promotes American interests abroad. The Department also provides support to U.S. citizens traveling or living overseas, issues passports and visas, and works to advance global peace, security, and prosperity. As the principal diplomatic arm of the federal government, the Department of State plays a vital role in shaping and implementing the country’s foreign policy objectives.
fields.Org IATI Name: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

name: HOT: Humanitarian Open Street Map Team

fields.Org Full Name: HOT: Humanitarian Open Street Map Team
fields.Org Description: HOT is an international team dedicated to humanitarian action and community development through open mapping. We work together to provide map data which revolutionises disaster management, reduces risks, and contributes to achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.

fields.Project Description: Managed by the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team, the Field Mapping Tasking Manager (FMTM) coordinates mapping campaigns in crisis zones through volunteer contributions. It organizes tasks, quality controls labeling, and integrates open geospatial datasets into humanitarian operational platforms.

Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

HOT is an international team dedicated to humanitarian action and community development through open mapping. The team collaborates to provide map data that revolutionizes disaster management, reduces risks, and contributes to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.

The HOT Summits are a series of conferences by the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team, that bring together people from around the world working to make open geographic data available to improve the welfare of people living in vulnerable and disaster prone areas using OpenStreetMap as a foundation.

LearnOSM offers clear, easy-to-understand, step-by-step guides designed to help users get started with contributing to OpenStreetMap and utilizing OpenStreetMap data. For those interested in organizing an OpenStreetMap workshop, LearnOSM also provides comprehensive trainer resources.

name: ACLED: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data

fields.Org Full Name: ACLED: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data
fields.Org Description: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED) is a disaggregated data collection, analysis, and crisis mapping initiative. ACLED collects information on the dates, actors, locations, fatalities, and types of all reported political violence and protest events around the world. The ACLED team conducts analysis to describe and explore conflict trends.

fields.Project Description: ACLED is a widely used conflict dataset that tracks the locations, dates, actors, and types of political violence and protest events across the world. Updated weekly, it covers over 150 countries and includes data on battles, riots, strategic developments, and civilian targeting. ACLED’s open-access data and analytical tools are used by policymakers, researchers, and humanitarian organizations to monitor conflict dynamics, assess risk, and support early warning systems and humanitarian planning.
The ACLED Conflict Alert System (CAST) is a conflict forecasting visualization platform designed to predict political violence events up to six months in the future for every country in the world.

ACLED Trendfinder offers an array of interconnected tools for tracking patterns of political violence and protest. Using the visualization platform, users can identify important changes in political violence and protest across and within countries, situate this activity within historical contexts, and spot early warning signs.
The Conflict Monitors cover key areas and are designed to support conflict analysis, violence-prevention initiatives, and efforts to monitor emerging crisis situations.

The Conflict Exposure Calculator integrates data from ACLED with population size estimates from WorldPop to estimate the civilian impact based on proximity to an event, event type, type of violent actor or specific armed group, location, and time.

fields.Org Description: IMPACT’s PANDA initiative aims to improve the effectiveness, efficiency and efficacy of humanitarian and development interventions. PANDA supports the entire humanitarian programme cycle, including programme design, assessments, baselines, monitoring and evaluation.

fields.Project Description: IMPACT’s PANDA builds capacities of local and international actors to understand crisis dynamics through training and tools in information management, assessments, monitoring and evaluation, and GIS. The initiative enhances partners’ analytical capabilities to improve the effectiveness and responsiveness of humanitarian interventions.

IMPACT’s PANDA initiative aims to improve the effectiveness, efficiency, and efficacy of humanitarian and development interventions. PANDA supports the entire humanitarian programme cycle, including programme design, assessments, baselines, monitoring, and evaluation.

fields.Org Description: WorldPop is an interdisciplinary applied research group focusing primarily on supporting improvement of the spatial demographic evidence base and the use of these data for health and development applications, including addressing the Sustainable Development Goals. Its mission is to enable decision makers to harness the power of spatial demographic data through high quality applied research, to achieve a vision of a world where everyone, everywhere is counted in decision making.

fields.Project Description: Provides standardized global administrative boundary datasets, essential for geospatial analysis and mapping. Open-access and regularly updated, these boundaries support humanitarian planning, statistical frameworks, and international data interoperability.

OCHA’s Common Operational Data Administrative Boundaries (COD‑AB) is a curated, harmonized global dataset aligned with OCHA’s COD standard. It is designed to support mapping, analysis, and coordination in humanitarian operations.

WorldPop is an interdisciplinary applied research group that focuses on supporting the improvement of the spatial demographic evidence base and the use of these data for health and development applications, including addressing the Sustainable Development Goals. The group’s mission is to enable decision makers to harness the power of spatial demographic data through high quality applied research, with the vision of a world where everyone, everywhere is counted in decision making.

fields.Project/Product Name: GRID3: Geo-Referenced Infrastructure and Demographic Data for Development
fields.Project Description: GRID3 provides high-resolution geospatial data, including population estimates, infrastructure mapping, and administrative boundaries, to support governments and organizations in planning, monitoring, and delivering services effectively.
MAP provides high-resolution maps of malaria risk and stability, combining epidemiological and environmental data to support global health planning, investment, and disease modeling.

WorldPop is an interdisciplinary applied research group that focuses on supporting the improvement of the spatial demographic evidence base and the use of these data for health and development applications, including addressing the Sustainable Development Goals. The group’s mission is to enable decision makers to harness the power of spatial demographic data through high quality applied research, with the vision of a world where everyone, everywhere is counted in decision making.

name: DHS: The Demographic and Health Survey

fields.Org Full Name: DHS: The Demographic and Health Survey
fields.Org Description: The DHS Program (Demographic and Health Surveys) is a primary source of data on health and population trends in developing countries, having provided technical assistance to over 300 surveys in more than 90 countries since 1984. They collect and disseminate nationally representative data on critical areas including fertility, family planning, maternal and child health, gender, HIV/AIDS, malaria, and nutrition. Funded by USAID and other donors, and implemented by ICF International, The DHS Program plays a vital role in advancing global understanding of health and population issues.

fields.Project Description: The Service Provision Assessment (SPA) is a health facility survey designed to collect information on service availability and Quality of Care (QoC) measures within a country’s health system. The SPA addresses the urgent need for actionable monitoring data in participating countries. It assesses the availability and quality of care for a wide range of services, with a particular focus on antenatal care (ANC), family planning (FP), maternity care, and sick child services. Quality of Care measures are evaluated across two dimensions: structural quality, which includes physical and human resources, and process quality, which encompasses the provision of care and the experience of care.

The Malaria Indicator Surveys (MIS) collect data on household ownership and use of mosquito nets, malaria prevention during pregnancy, and access to effective treatment for fever in children. These surveys often include biomarker testing for malaria and anemia, enabling countries to assess progress toward malaria control targets.

The Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) provide comprehensive and nationally representative data for monitoring and evaluating population, health, and nutrition indicators. These surveys support evidence-based decision-making and program design in developing countries by collecting high-quality information on fertility, family planning, maternal and child health, and HIV/AIDS.

The Key Indicators Survey (KIS) is designed to address the monitoring and evaluation needs of programs engaged in population and health activities in developing countries. It is particularly useful for generating data for small areas, such as regions, districts, or catchment areas, which may be the focus of individual projects. However, the KIS can also be applied in nationally representative surveys. The KIS tool comprises questionnaires, interviewer’s manuals, sampling guidelines, and a tabulation plan.

fields.Org Description: Data Friendly Space (DFS) provides trustworthy digital tools and actionable data for social impact organisations to fulfil their mission. We believe that the international community holds not just the knowledge, but also the responsibility to utilise emerging technologies and data to better prepare for and respond to humanitarian needs, support the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and accelerate climate action.

fields.Project Description: GANNET is a real-time, end-to-end Generative AI platform that combines near real-time assistance, analytics, and monitoring features for humanitarian data collaboration and effective decision-making.

name: UNESCO: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

fields.Org Full Name: UNESCO: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
fields.Org Description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is the agency of the United Nations contributing to building peace through international cooperation in education, the sciences and culture.
fields.Org IATI Name: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO)

fields.Project Description: This Observatory provides updated information on the killing of journalists since 1993 and on the judicial status of condemned cases since 2006. It also provides public access to country responses to UNESCO's requests for information into the judicial status of ongoing and unresolved cases. You may browse the full list of killed journalists and search for visual statistics and data.

fields.Project/Product Name: Cultural Heritage in Crisis Zones Data
fields.Project Description: The List of World Heritage in Danger is intended to inform the international community about conditions that threaten the defining characteristics for which a property was inscribed on the World Heritage List, and to encourage the implementation of corrective actions.

UNESCO’s platform delivers open access data on emergency-affected education systems, including enrollment figures, disruptions, and inclusion metrics. This resource supports global response planning in crises and displacement settings by providing comprehensive and reliable information on the state of education in emergencies.

fields.Org Description: We are a non-profit organisation collaborating with partners around the world to prepare for and respond to humanitarian emergencies. We strive to ensure global, regional, national and local disaster management and humanitarian agencies have access to the maps, visualised data, information and analysis that they need to make key decisions, at the right times, to save lives and reduce suffering.

fields.Project Description: When major emergencies occur, MapAction provides surge support to partners at short notice, enabling them to make sense of chaotic, dangerous, and rapidly evolving situations and to coordinate the most effective response. MapAction operates both in-country and remotely. The organization’s well-rehearsed deployment model ensures that mapping professionals can be on the scene within 24-48 hours of a disaster striking. Even before arriving in-country, they begin collecting data and information that will be crucial in helping to coordinate the global response and ensure that aid reaches those who need it most.

fields.Org Description:
The International Crisis Group is an independent organisation working to prevent wars and shape policies that will build a more peaceful world.
Crisis Group sounds the alarm to prevent deadly conflict. We build support for the good governance and inclusive politics that enable societies to flourish. We engage directly with a range of conflict actors to seek and share information, and to encourage intelligent action for peace.

fields.Project Description: CrisisWatch is a global conflict tracker and early warning tool designed to help prevent deadly violence. It keeps decision-makers up-to-date with developments in over 70 conflicts and crises every month, identifying trends and alerting them to risks of escalation and opportunities to advance peace. In addition, CrisisWatch monitors over 50 situations through “standby monitoring” to provide timely information if developments indicate a drift toward violence or instability. Entries dating back to 2003 offer easily searchable conflict histories for the asset CrisisWatch.

fields.Agency/Department Name: European Union Emergency Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF)
Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)

fields.Project Description: Developed by the International Crisis Group, EEARTH is a revolutionary early warning system designed to identify climate-driven conflict pathways in the Horn of Africa. By integrating both quantitative and qualitative data, it offers a comprehensive approach to climate-security risks. Initially piloted in Somalia and South Sudan, EEARTH provides insights into the underlying causes of conflict risks. Its innovative approach is geared towards anticipating, preventing, and addressing the repercussions of climate-related security threats.

name: HIIK: Heidelberg Institute for International Conflict Research

fields.Org Full Name: HIIK: Heidelberg Institute for International Conflict Research
fields.Org Description: The Heidelberg Institute for International Conflict Research (HIIK) is an independent and interdisciplinary registered association located at the Department of Political Science at the University of Heidelberg. Since 1991, the HIIK has been committed to the distribution of knowledge about the emergence, course and settlement of interstate and intrastate political conflicts. The Conflict Barometer is published annually and contains the current research results.

fields.Project Description: Since 1992, the Conflict Barometer has qualitatively and quantitatively recorded the dynamics of political conflicts, both violent and non-violent, worldwide. In accordance with the HIIK methodology, violent conflicts are classified according to their intensity into violent crises (intensity 3), limited wars (intensity 4), and wars (intensity 5). Non-violent conflicts are divided into disputes (intensity 1) and non-violent crises (intensity 2). The annual report is supplemented by conflict maps, graphics, and datasets as well as Spotlight texts that shed light on the wider context of current conflict dynamics.

Map Kit is an annual collection of global and regional conflict maps derived from the Conflict Barometer, presenting national and subnational conflict trends alongside downloadable underlying data where available. The series offers ready-to-use static maps covering all world regions, supporting comparative conflict analysis and situational awareness.

fields.Org Description: Coventry University focuses on applied teaching and industry-linked learning, emphasizing practical skills, professional accreditation, and career-oriented programs in fields such as engineering, business, and health, while expanding its profile through international partnerships and vocational innovation.

fields.Project Description: PeaceRep distributes the PA-X Tracker, an innovative digital tool designed to provide data-driven insights that support peace and transition processes. The suite of PeaceTech tools within the PA-X Tracker enables users to track and monitor the progress and implementation of peace and transition initiatives.
